carousel_items: Remicade is a medication that's given as an infusion at your doctor's office or clinic.
It's very important to read the patient Medication Guide when you first start using Remicade.
It's possible to get an allergic reaction to Remicade either immediately during the treatment or a several days after stopping it. Your doctor can give you medicines that'll lower this risk.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start taking Remicade and periodically during treatment.

Remicade lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, cough, or flu-like symptoms. Children seem to get more infections than adults, so keep a close eye on them.

If you have a young child, let their doctor know if you were on Remicade while pregnant or nursing. It can increase their risk of infections for several months after your last dose and can delay their vaccine schedule.

basics.benefits_moa: Remicade is a biologic response modifier. It works in the immune system to block a protein called TNF (tumor necrosis factor). Blocking TNF relieves symptoms and prevents disease progression.
basics.bottom_line: Remicade is very effective at calming down your immune system, but you have to get each dose at your doctor's office and watch out for serious side effects.
downsides: You have to get every dose through an IV infusion at your doctor's office.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Remicade has a higher risk of serious infusion-related side effects during or after it's given since it's injected right into your veins. Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose that may lower this risk.

Remicade lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.
Not the best choice if you have heart failure.

Talk to your baby's doctor if you're pregnant or breast-feeding. When women in a study took Remicade, the medicine was found in their breast milk 2 to 3 days after each dose, and in the baby's blood 6 months after they were born.

downsides_processed.orig: You have to get every dose through an IV infusion at your doctor's office.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Remicade has a higher risk of serious infusion-related side effects during or after it's given since it's injected right into your veins. Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose that may lower this risk.

Remicade lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.
Not the best choice if you have heart failure.

Talk to your baby's doctor if you're pregnant or breast-feeding. When women in a study took Remicade, the medicine was found in their breast milk 2 to 3 days after each dose, and in the baby's blood 6 months after they were born.

upsides: Treats certain types of arthritis and gastrointestinal conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Remicade has almost two decades of clinical trial data and real-life experience with millions of people who have used it.
Initial dosing to introduce Remicade to your body might be a hassle, but then you only need to take it every 6-8 weeks depending on your condition.

userStories.tip: Remicade changed my life. Before I started it, I was in constant pain and had a difficult time getting out of a chair or turning over in bed. Now I have only minor pain and live a full and happy life.
Have gotten severe psoriasis from the medication.
Make sure to get lots of rest for the rest of the day. Don't go on a plane within a day or two or you will get sick.
userStories.identifier: early 30s single with 70 hour work week

userStories.tip: I have been in remission since my first dose!

drugs.name: Remicade

carousel_items_processed.orig: Remicade is a medication that's given as an infusion at your doctor's office or clinic.
It's very important to read the patient Medication Guide when you first start using Remicade.
It's possible to get an allergic reaction to Remicade either immediately during the treatment or a several days after stopping it. Your doctor can give you medicines that'll lower this risk.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start taking Remicade and periodically during treatment.

Remicade lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, cough, or flu-like symptoms. Children seem to get more infections than adults, so keep a close eye on them.

If you have a young child, let their doctor know if you were on Remicade while pregnant or nursing. It can increase their risk of infections for several months after your last dose and can delay their vaccine schedule.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Remicade has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Remicade has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Remicade may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. If you have mild heart failure and your condition hasn't improved on any other medicine talk to your doctor to see if Remicade is right for you. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Remicade may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. If you have mild heart failure and your condition hasn't improved on any other medicine talk to your doctor to see if Remicade is right for you. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Remicade can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Remicade. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Remicade can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Remicade. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Malignancy
risks_warnings.description: Based on how Remicade works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Remicade.

description_processed.orig: Based on how Remicade works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Remicade.

risks_warnings.title: Nervous system effects
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Remicade can cause nervous system conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and Guillain Barre syndrome. If you currently have a nervous system condition, your doctor will watch you closely while you're taking Remicade since it can make them worse. Let your doctor know right away if you notice numbness or tingling, weakness in arms or legs, vision problems or dizziness.

description_processed.orig: Although rare, Remicade can cause nervous system conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and Guillain Barre syndrome. If you currently have a nervous system condition, your doctor will watch you closely while you're taking Remicade since it can make them worse. Let your doctor know right away if you notice numbness or tingling, weakness in arms or legs, vision problems or dizziness.

risks_warnings.title: Blood problems
risks_warnings.description: Remicade can affect blood cells that help you fight infection and stop bleeding. Let your doctor know if you develop a fever that doesn't go away, or you easily bruise, or bleed. You may need to stop taking this medicine.

description_processed.orig: Remicade can affect blood cells that help you fight infection and stop bleeding. Let your doctor know if you develop a fever that doesn't go away, or you easily bruise, or bleed. You may need to stop taking this medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Liver injury
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Remicade can cause serious liver injury. You'll need to have your liver enzymes tested regularly. If liver enzymes are significantly elevated and you have appetite/weight loss, stomach discomfort, vomiting, and notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, change in stool color, and skin rash you should stop treatment with Remicade until you can be completely assessed,
